messages: 69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (09:23): i really don't understand the vision people on hybi have for websockets
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (09:24): in what world does it make sense to talk about websockets messages being "dispatched using the platform's mime mechanism"?
ad7340c0d2664b131f969961d78c86b2 (09:36): I haven't followed along on that conversation, 69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e
ad7340c0d2664b131f969961d78c86b2 (09:36): although, some of the things proposed do sound a little bit more complicated then what's needed
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (09:55): ad7340c0d2664b131f969961d78c86b2: it's not so much that they're complicated so much as as far as i can tell, they make no sense at all
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (09:55): it'd be like if someone was talking about how HTTP should allow you to change nick
ad7340c0d2664b131f969961d78c86b2 (09:55): okay, similar idea
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (09:55): or if someone was talking about how IRC didn't let you select the printer driver
ad7340c0d2664b131f969961d78c86b2 (09:56): well of course irc should let you choose your printer driver, isn't that what your irc server does?
ad7340c0d2664b131f969961d78c86b2 (09:56): my included the kitchen sink.
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (09:59): less than 24 hours left on the current HTML WG polls
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (10:10): 69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e: The MIME stuff confuses the hell out of me
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (10:10): I have no idea why you would want that
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (10:15): well, it's pretty clear Greg still wants his bidirectional HTTP rather than TCP for browsers
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (10:15): but I don't get why he argues for mime for the whole stream
edb259c0e0038f38bb200bc20c8cbf7e (10:15): that makes no sense at all
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (10:20): do those who want bidi HTTP want it to be implemented in browsers?
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (10:21): But it's not clear what they rally envision
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (10:21): e.g. there was lots of stuff about doing dispatch based on content-type
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (10:22): But in most websockets cases I can think of, that makes no sense
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (10:22): Anyway, my conclusion is that the whole thing is just a bad idea because it is additional complexity
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (10:22): and makes the protocol less generic
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (10:23): I am more worried by real issues like framing / the handshake
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (10:24): what's the real problem with those?
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (10:28): For the handshake there is some question about the security properties
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (10:28): Although it looks like wss will change
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (10:29): For the framing there is a tenion between the belief that sentinal markers are more secure when sending, and that it is harder to write the recieving code
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (10:30): the only change i'm aware of for wss: is the minor addition of the hook into the nextprotoneg feature
b25b6b77a0087ff8385941e5545d32ea (10:31): 69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e: That was what I meant, I think
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (10:32): that's not much of a change :-)
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (10:32): this stuff really needs to be wrapped up and shipped
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (10:37): have there been any positive effects from taking the protocol to the IETF?
aad758927f12b95b0cd1961f8dbee690 (11:04): waves to a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2
aad758927f12b95b0cd1961f8dbee690 (11:05): Hey, Mike, I want to introduce you my friend, 79a85932d0713a6fb108e502cf269484.
aad758927f12b95b0cd1961f8dbee690 (11:05): He is my high school classmate and very interested in HTML5.
aad758927f12b95b0cd1961f8dbee690 (11:05): Most importantly, he's going to be a google employee next year :)
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (11:05): excellent
aad758927f12b95b0cd1961f8dbee690 (11:06): Of course I want him to help promote W3C-related work in Taiwan. Hehe.
aad758927f12b95b0cd1961f8dbee690 (11:06): There's little information about HTML5 in Taiwan, honestly.
79a85932d0713a6fb108e502cf269484 (11:07): But to begin with, I should mention that I am interested in it but not familiar with it..
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (11:07): http://diveintohtml5.org/ is a good place to start learning
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (11:07): and http://html5doctor.com/
aad758927f12b95b0cd1961f8dbee690 (11:08): a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2: Also he is interested in (using) P2P technology. :)
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (11:08): and for a quick overview of the differences from HTML4, http://dev.w3.org/html5/html4-differences/
aad758927f12b95b0cd1961f8dbee690 (11:08): I noticed that recently there's some discussion about possible P2P with HTML5?
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (11:08): yeah
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (11:09): 69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e has a draft spec of an idea
aad758927f12b95b0cd1961f8dbee690 (11:09): pointer?
a9b326df4e6da61c5b6f5e1058be83a2 (11:09): http://www.whatwg.org/specs/web-apps/current-work/complete/commands.html#peer-to-peer-connections
aad758927f12b95b0cd1961f8dbee690 (11:09): Ah, thanks. How new is this, I wonder.
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (11:09): in particular, http://lists.whatwg.org/htdig.cgi/whatwg-whatwg.org/2010-July/027129.html
aad758927f12b95b0cd1961f8dbee690 (11:10): Thanks!
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (11:11): nn
79a85932d0713a6fb108e502cf269484 (11:11): Speaking of P2P, is there some kind of real-time video streaming of sharing methods available now?
